text: Patient: So do we schedule the appointment today? Doctor: For coming downtown? Yeah somebody will call you once we have everything. Patient: And so we’re not scheduling it today. Doctor: Do you want to come later on this week? Tell me what day works well and how long you need to think about the consent and everything? Patient: Just coming to the midtown? Family Member: To do the tests honey. Doctor: Yeah to do the testing and to do the… Family Member: Is this the long day. Is the first day the long day? Doctor: Oh no, no that’s not treatment day. It’s just pre – all of the screening and testing will happen that day. Family Member: So what would that – that’s an echo and what else? Doctor: Yeah I think the echo and the specialized blood work that we have to send out. Family Member: So there’s just echo and blood work.

text: Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm.

text: Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s nothing in the blood work all your scans are clean, then you can say wow I see nothing Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: So what is – can he take anything to help him sleep? Like natural? Doctor: You can try melatonin. Family Member: Melatonin. That’s right. Doctor: I suggest stop drinking at seven p.m. and you’ll be a miracle. You won’t even get up that much. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’ll say, oh, my, gosh, I’m awake and I didn’t get up. Patient: I’ll go with that line of action first. Doctor: And then you’re going to say, boy, that doctor, she’s really smart. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Be sure you don’t like, you know, sleep so hard that you forget to pee if you actually have to pee. Doctor: I’m just saying seven p.m. Okay. Bye. Patient: Okay. So I got – she took – oh, I do, right here. Doctor: You do have sheet to go.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
